title: The Hidden People’s Tea Party
description: Icelandic people believe there are hidden people out there.
Arnbjörg Kristín Konráðsdóttir and I held a tea party for the hidden people.
All plants were collected from local vegetation.
Summer 2019
at gilfelagiddeiglan in Akureyri, Iceland

title: Aspira Clip 2017
description: Aspira Clip is a Berlin-based company that specializes in nose clips.
In 2017, I created botanical arrangements for their new product advertisement.
Photo by Luise Kalinka

title: Abandoned #2
description: Flowers are Documents II was displayed at ar/ge kunst in Bolzano, Italy from June 22nd to July 29th, 2017. This second installment of Flowers are Documents featured new flower compositions alongside those by Kapwani Kiwanga (Flowers for Africa) and Natalie Czech (A Critic's Bouquet), which were originally installed on May 26th and have naturally changed over the course of the exhibition.

Rie Ono and Martina della Valle created an Ikebana using wild local vegetation gathered during a workshop. The exhibition also included new pieces by Haris Epaminonda, Oliver Laric, and Paul Thuile, featuring a vase, a collage, and an exhibition, respectively. These works were displayed alongside Bruno Munari's book "A Flower with Love" (1973) and Ettore Sottsass Jr's photograph "I Designed a Vase for my Fiancé, Death Valley" (1977).
Four photos from the top by Luca Guadagnini, ©ar/ge kunst, 2017
Three photos from the bottom by Martina della Valle

title: One Flower, One Leaf #2
description: Rie Ono and Martina della Valle led an Ikebana workshop titled "One Flower, One Leaf #2" at MAXXI in Rome, Italy. All materials for the workshop were collected from the riverside near the museum.

The workshop aimed to connect the traditional Japanese art of Ikebana with a site-specific examination of the contemporary urban landscape. It explored concepts such as the study of marginal and refusal areas in the landscape, the impact of human intervention on urban vegetation, the value of the concept of time and emptiness, and the ability of Ikebana (as well as the medium of photography) to enhance through a process of de-contextualization.

After a brief introduction to the origins and principles of Ikebana, the participants went on a walk to collect spontaneous vegetal materials (such as plants,flowers,and branches) from the surrounding landscape.
— one flower, one leaf from the website of Martina della Valle
Location: MAXXI, Rome, Italy.
Photo by Martina della Valle

title: Abandoned#1
description: "Wabi-Sabi" exhibition view: artworks "Wabi-Sabi" by MdV and Ikebana arrangements "Abandoned" by Rie Ono

An ikebana installation "Abandoned" for an exhibition "Wabi-Sabi" presented by artist Martina Della Valle and curated by Chiara Ruberti and Luca Carradori at Dryphoto arte contemporanea, Prato, Italy from 30 September until 15 November 2016. All materials are picked in the abandoned field around the gallery and the installation was left until the end of exhibition to show a life of ikebana.
We also had an ikebana workshop "one flower, one leaf #1" on 24 and 25 September 2016. Please see more information about the workshop here.
Photo by Martina della Valle

title: One Flower,One Leaf #Ad
description: Photos are used for advertisement of the first collaborated ikebana workshop with Martina Della Valle, "one flower, one leaf". All materials are picked on the riverside which is located in the center of Berlin, June 2016.

"The idea of the workshop starts from Martina della Valle with the aim to connect the traditional Japanese art of Ikebana (the art of arranging flowers) with a site-specific observation of the contemporary urban landscape. Analysing the founding concepts of the research of della Valle (in particular of "Wabi-Sabi"), themes such as the study of marginal and refusal areas on the landscape, the traces of the human intervention on the urban vegetation, the value of the concept of time and emptiness and the capacity of Ikebana (as also of the photographic medium) to exalt through a process of de-contextualization. After a brief introduction about origins and principles of the art of Ikebana, the research takes place on the surrounding vegetal landscape, walking to select the vegetal spontaneous materials (plants, flowers, branches..). After that, guided by the ikebana teacher, the participants will create their own Ikebana arrangement. The photographic documentation of the resulting creations, will build up an ideal portrait of the natural native landscape mapping the specific working area.
— one flower, one leaf by Martina della Valle
Location: Macha-macha, Berlin, Germany
Photo by Martina della Valle

title: Aspira Clip 2016
description: Plants decollation for Aspira Clip's 2016 product shooting.
Art direction Trouni Tiet & Rie Ono
Photo by Trouni Tiet

title: IKEBANANA
description: It was a spontaneous fun project. My friends and I organized an event at an abandoned Egyptian restaurant before it had been demolished.
Theme of its event is localization of Japanese traditional culture such as tea ceremony, ikebana into Berliners but keep its originality and philosophy "impermanence", "ichigo ichie (一期一会)".

We usually use a specific equipment to put branches up. However, I could not find it in Berlin therefore, I came up with the idea to use bananas instead of the equipment. Besides, this is the beginning of my plants hunting in Berlin.
I picked all branches and leaves from Hasenheide park in front of the venue. We ate bananas after the event also used them for banana pancakes on the day next.
The event : Tea gathering for sky god was held on 14 September 2015 in Berlin Germany.
Hosted by
Mai Ueda (tea ceremony)
Rie Ono (live ikebana)
Joschto & Tamaki (food+sencha cocktail)
Yumi Tanabe (mitate yoga)
Egon Elliut (sound scape)
Sponsored by Macha macha
Photo by Aki Makita
